p:
The reproduction number, R, which measures the average number of secondary cases from each infected person, is a useful metric for assessing the transmission potential of an emerging pathogen such as MERS-CoV ( Lloyd-Smith et al., 2009, Wolfe et al., 2007). If R < 1 then infections occur in isolated clusters as self-limited chains of transmission, and persistence of the disease requires continued animal-to-human infections ( Anderson and May, 1991). When averaged over all reported cases, two recent studies have estimated an overall R (denoted R overall) to be in a range of 0.42–0.92 ( Breban et al., 2013, Cauchemez et al., 2014), thus diminishing the concern of MERS-CoV epidemic spread. In contrast, when R is evaluated for just the index cases originating from animal-to-human transmission, estimates (denoted R
i ) can be as high as 1.5 ( Cauchemez et al., 2014), suggesting that epidemic spread is possible.
